title.narrative: A Bright Future - Afghan Youth Making it Work

description.narrative: The Bright Future programme is designed for the younger generation in the urban environment of Kabul, an area with a high prevalence of university graduates and under- or unemployed youth. Specifically targeting urban, educated young Afghan men and women, the programme aims to convene a vibrant community of young professionals who are able and willing to contribute positively to the economic growth of their cities and country as either entrepreneurs or employees.

The private sector in Afghanistan is currently relatively small, and does not yet function as a job engine. The main reason why young people are not setting up businesses is because the environment for doing business is prohibitive, fraught with real and perceived risks, obstacles and constraints, which discourage potential entrepreneurs from starting new businesses. Of these risks some, such as political instability and insecurity, are outside of the control of individual entrepreneurs, others, such as corruption, access to finance and land and a non-competitive environment, are obstacles, which can be managed with assistance and support. Nepotism and corruption play an important role in the business sphere, in terms of exclusive instead of inclusive access to resources (land, finance). For startups the first needs are office, access to seed capital, access to training and coaching, for SME’s the needs are access to finance and land and access to business development services. For both startups as SME’s, skill development in particular related to business planning and marketing, building networks, learning how to deal with corruption and insecurity, building resilience, will be required to build businesses in a difficult environment. In the labour market, the withdrawal of military forces and the reduction of aid-related jobs has had a significant impact, resulting in the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs. Although predictions based on government policies point into the direction of economic growth in the near future, in particular in the service sector, it is still unclear how, when and where this will manifest itself and how this will impact employment opportunities for urban-based, well-educated young people in particular. While acknowledging that a skills mismatch and poor job quality are causes for concern, the immediate problem in the labour market to address is a gap between the supply of well-educated and skilled young workers and the limited demand for skilled employees in a depressed economy. The reasons why well-educated urban youngsters cannot find employment are: • Lack of (suitable) jobs • Supply of qualified, highly skilled jobseekers far outstripping the demand, and • Corruption and nepotism in the hiring process The primary reason why existing laws are not being implemented is pervasive corruption. Poor knowledge and understanding of the laws, on the side of entrepreneurs and employees as well as government and employers, makes the law into a potential vehicle for corruption by predators. The lack of economic opportunities is one of the root causes for especially Afghan urban men to migrate. Youth unemployment in Afghanistan is dashing the dreams of millions of young people. A severely underdeveloped labour market, weak protection of property rights, opaqueness in the hiring processes, corruption and the horse trading of positions in return for political support and favours leaves many young urban Afghan men and women with hardly any hope of a prosperous future in their own country. Also the withdrawal of military forces and the reduction of aid-related jobs have had a significant impact resulting in the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs. While acknowledging that skills mismatch and poor job quality are causes for concern, the immediate problem in the labour market is a gap between the oversupply of well-educated and skilled young people and the limited demand for skilled employees in a depressed economy. With a relatively small private sector and a business environment that is prohibitive, fraught with real and perceived risks, potential entrepreneurs are often discouraged to starting new businesses. Of these risks some, such as political instability and insecurity, are outside the control of individual entrepreneurs, others, such as corruption, access to finance and land and a non-competitive environment, are obstacles which can be managed with assistance and support. Moreover, nepotism and corruption play an important role, both in the hiring process (in that knowing the right people is more important than having the right skills) as well as in the general business sphere, in terms of exclusive instead of inclusive access to resources, which increases the cost of doing business. Finally, even though existing Afghan laws are relatively progressive, the implementation of these laws is lacking. One of the reasons for this is the difficulty for both entrepreneurs and employees, as well as designated power actors, to navigate these complex (provisions in) existing laws and the ambiguity in the interpretation of these laws. Those working in relevant institutions often do not have a good (and shared) understanding of the law. Some important areas, such as the relations between employee and employer for example, are not well defined in labour law. Also, officials do not always know what their mandate is. This makes the law into a potential vehicle for corruption by predators. The above paints a very grim picture for young people in Afghanistan. With our programme we aim to stimulate economic growth in an economy that provides opportunities for all Afghans. The change we would love to see is on the one hand that the barriers that prevent young Afghans from actively participating in the economy are removed and on the other hand that young people have the faith and confidence that they can build up a future in Afghanistan, and wholeheartedly choose to stay in Afghanistan and contribute to the future of their country. The change we expect to see at least is that the barriers are reduced, the chances of young urban Afghans to start a business or to find gainful employment are improved, and that they are better positioned on the labour market. We also expect that as a result of our programme young urban Afghans will have a more positive outlook on and feel confident about their economic prospects and no longer consider embarking on a dangerous journey to Europe as their only option for a flourishing future.

Female farmers deserve better

description.narrative: Teso sub-region covers the districts of Soroti, Kaberamaido, Katakwi, Amuria, Bukedea, Kumi, Ngora and Serere in the North Eastern part of Uganda. The population of the region is estimated at 2,207,800 (UBOS, 2014), who are mainly the Iteso, Kuman and Bakenyi. The communities derive their livelihoods mainly from mixed farming involving crop production and livestock keeping and also involved in trade of both crop and livestock products together with other merchandise. The region experiences a bimodal type of rainfall of about 1000-1200mm per annum, with two cropping seasons. The vegetation in the sub-region can best be described as grassland savannah. The soils are mainly sandy loam with a variation from sandy to loamy soils depending on the terrain.

This project is aiming at improving resilience, post-harvest losses and income. The program has the following three objectives:
- 1 Increasing harvest by training and techniques - 2 Less post-harvest losses by improved storage methods - 3 Increasing income by improving access to markets and financial resources.

This project targets 15.000 farmers (60 % female) and their families. The total number of indirect beneficiaries is over 75.000 people. from 5 district of Teso region: Amuria, Serere, ,Soroti, Kaberamaido and Katakwi

SP Afghanistan - Strategic Partnership

description.narrative: Afghan women and youth are better secured, their legal rights are protected, and they are actively engaged and represented in peace talk processes. • Increased trust in customary and statutory justice providers by citizens and particularly women. • The health system is more accountable and responsive to the needs of population providing efficient, quality, and equitable health service to all Afghans. • Communities in mining areas live in a safe environment, enjoy decent livelihoods and social services and influence decisions related to mining and their well-being

The strategic partnership program focuses on 4 topics in Afghanistan: Inclusive and Engendered Peace, Security and Access to Justice, Health System Reform and Extractives. In Afghanistan, ongoing insecurity and conflict is restricting both women and youth, as well as civil society organizations (CSOs), from actively contributing to peacebuilding and participating in decision-making processes. Poverty and unemployment are increasingly affecting society’s most vulnerable groups. Moreover, the National Unity Government has not yet sufficiently addressed the participation of these groups.
The inclusive peace trajectory focuses on increasing the role and engagement of youth and women in peace processes. Supported by the Afghan Women’s Network (AWN) women advocates in eight provinces discuss women’s concerns and recommendations about women’s role in the peace process with provincial-level peace councils and at a higher level. Meetings are held with the First Lady to take up the concerns. Furthermore, youth is trained in lobbying and advocacy, peace-building, and leadership and meet with the provincial peace committees to share youth concerns. Support is provided to the Youth Deputy Minister and his department.
In the trajectory on access to Partner network SALAH focuses on improving the functioning of local courts and justice departments. Community members are trained to monitor court procedures and functioning. These monitoring reports and findings are discussed with justice sector authorities at the provincial and national levels to advocate for reform.
In the health trajectory the Alliance of Health Organizations (AHO) is training the provincial health authorities and community health Shuras in eight provinces on alternative health financing . The capacities of community representatives is strengthened to engage with policymakers at provincial and national level. AHO works with the Ministry of Public Health with the objective of engaging local leaders and health Shura members in PPHCC meetings.
The extractives trajectory aims to ensure that communities benefit more from mining. This is essential since the government of Afghanistan and the international community have identified the mining sector as a source for supporting development. Partner organization the Human Rights Research and Advocacy Consortium focuses on improving the regulation of the mining industry and increasing community involvement, and advocates to ensure that the Ministry of Mining and Petroleum and the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs take responsibility for their role in monitoring labor conditions in mining sites. Additionally, the program facilitates the establishment of a CSO network that monitors local situations and reports to the relevant authorities.

title.narrative: Number of security and justice institutions (formal and informal) strengthened to provide better security and justice services

description.narrative: Count institutions supported by the project in improving their functioning resulting in better service provision towards vulnerable groups. Justice institutions can be part of the formal justice system or implement informal, customary law. Security institution include police, armed forces or peacekeeping missions. Institutions can operate at national level like Departments of Ministries or at local level like police stations and local courts. Specify in the comments which institutions have strengthened their capacities. Institutions are considered "strengthened" if they have become more responsive, accountable and inclusive.

title.narrative: Number of people with improved access to more responsive, accountable and inclusive security and justice services

description.narrative: "The indicators measures the impact resulting from project interventions. Only count the number of people who gained access to services because of improved functioning of security of justice institutions in the project area during the reporting period. The improved service can result from a better (implementation of) legislative framework and/or strengthened capacities of the institutions. Since the number is likely to be based on calculation, a precise justification of how this was done needs to be provided (in comment section). This indicator can be linked to indicators for: 1) improved legislation . However, improved legislation can NOT be assumed to benefit the entire population of the project area, and any claimed number of people m by calculating the people directly benefitting from their improved services of these institutions. Justice institutions can be part of the formal justice system or implement informal, customary law. Security institution include police, armed forces or peacekeeping missions."

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Local people around mining areas, who received information about the social and environmental impact of mining, are participating in community-based monitoring of mining ensure transparency and accountability.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Women representatives had consultation meetings with German, US, Turkey and Canada embassies to lobby for support to participate in the peace talks. Women advocators organized in a lobby network to share women concerns on peace talks with High Peace Council. Youth groups conducted social media campaign through Facebook page (Youth as Peace Makers) for thier involvement in peace talk. With purpose to put youth involvement in peace talk in government agenda together with other CSOs. The youth coalition conducted several meetings with the High Peace Council and Provincial Council to emphasize on youth participation in the peace process and to reflect on important performance lead by youth at provincial level and district level in targeted provinces. The youth coalition supported by AWN also had lobby meeting with the president, first lady, deputy minister of youth, minister of ministry of Information and Culture, Ministry of women affair and shared their crucial recommendation, challenges, and findings identified by youth on participation importance of youth participation in peace talks. (Security and Access to Justice): Local CSOs, community representatives and media actors monitor court cases regularly and record the human rights violations in five targeted provinces.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Women representatives had consultation meetings with German, US, Turkey and Canada embassies to lobby for support to participate in the peace talks. Women advocators organized in a lobby network to share women concerns on peace talks with High Peace Council. Youth groups conducted social media campaign through Facebook page (Youth as Peace Makers) for thier involvement in peace talk. With purpose to put youth involvement in peace talk in government agenda together with other CSOs. The youth coalition conducted several meetings with the High Peace Council and Provincial Council to emphasize on youth participation in the peace process and to reflect on important performance lead by youth at provincial level and district level in targeted provinces. The youth coalition supported by AWN also had lobby meeting with the president, first lady, deputy minister of youth, minister of ministry of Information and Culture, Ministry of women affair and shared their crucial recommendation, challenges, and findings identified by youth on participation importance of youth participation in peace talks. (Security and Access to Justice): Local CSOs, community representatives and media actors monitor court cases regularly and record the human rights violations in five targeted provinces.

OUTCOME(S): (Inclusive Health): Communities and members of Kabul Provincial Directorate Committees (PDC) engaged in the joint lobby and their awareness raised on the increment of national healthcare budget through awareness-raising sessions. As a result, communities and PDC members doing lobby and advocacy with the Afghanistan government and parliament for an increase in health sector budget and improvement of health services.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Youth members of local communities’ who participated in story telling sessions in eight targeted provinces (Kabul, Herat, Kandahar, Paktia, Bamyan, Nangrahar, Balkh & Kunduz) raised their voices through social media on promoting social peace in order to increase: 1. the level of local community awareness about social peace, and 2. asked for cease fire and peace agreement between Taliban and government.

title.narrative: A) Civil society partners (CSOs) and Cordaid increase their capacity to influence and engage in dialogue with policy makers, politicians and companies

comment.narrative: (Engendered peace): Women advocators organized in a lobby network to share women concerns on peace talks with High Peace Council. High Peace Council involved three women in country level peace negotiations as result of women advocators lobby with government and High Peace Council.

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): Chief justice (Head of Supreme Court) is showing more cooperation towards Salah consortium, because of Salah is working hard to increase its visibility at both the provincial and national level. Salah's activities include: monthly coordination meetings with justice actors, publication of research on public’s confidence of formal and informal justice systems, legal empowerment through media (TV & Radios) at the provincial level, publication of Salah journal provided the platform for Salah to do evidence-based advocacy both at the provincial and national levels. (Inclusive Health): Cordaid Afghanistan team is working with new partner organisation Afghan Health & Development Services (AHDS) to prepare an activity plan and budget starting from August to December 2019. Cordaid provided orientation session on the SP programme and invited the team to take part in the second quarterly review for learning proposes. (Extractives): FRD (Fast Relief and Development), a young national NGO working on advocacy, human rights and community awareness in Afghanistan, has become the new partner for extractives. FRD will start their activities on first July 2019 and took active part in second quarterly review workshop for learning proposes.

(Extractives): (Q4) Local communities know the mining cycle and engaged with local authorities. / (Q2) Awareness raising sessions are started and first awareness training is given to youth committee members. / (Q1) 0 /

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): After several coordination meetings with media and Ministry of Information and Culture on role of women and youth in the peace process, eight media channels at zonal level (Kabul, Herat, Balkh, Kandahar, Bamyan, Ningarhar, Paktia and, Kunduz) reflected the role of youth in the peace process through conducting the round table discussion and invited youth from AWN youth coalition at the zonal level.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Local communities’ members participated in story telling sessions in eight targeted provinces (Kabul, Herat, Kandahar, Paktia, Bamyan, Nangrahar, Balkh & Kunduz) and discussed problems of the daily safety situation.

title.narrative: K) National decision makers initiate policy processes with inclusive civil society engagement

comment.narrative: (Extractives): MoMP had amendment in mining law and asked CSOs inputs for process of amendment.

(Inclusive health services): (Q4) International community committed to support Afghanistan health system in Brussel Conference and World Bank supporting healh system through funding via MoF and MoPH. / (Q2) PPP regulation is finalized and passed to MoJ – Ministry of Justice for official approval. / (Q1) International community committed to support Afghanistan health system in Brussel Conference. /

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Afghanistan government announced the list peace talk delegation for negotiation with Taliban. Out of 21 members there 5 women and 2 youth representatives.
/ (Inclusive Health): MoF submitted 2020 national budget to parliament with increase in health budget and convinced Members of Parliament to approve the increased health budget for 2020.
/ (Extractives): Ministry of Mining and Petroleum (MoMP) in partnership with CSOs and community started a country-wide survey to identify and ban the illegal extraction of major metals and mineral resources. Government map illegal mining activities and create a registry of companies and actors involved in illegal mining.

/ (Inclusive Health): MoF submitted 2020 national budget to parliament with increase in health budget and convinced Members of Parliament to approve the increased health budget for 2020.
/ (Extractives): Ministry of Mining and Petroleum (MoMP) in partnership with CSOs and community started a country-wide survey to identify and ban the illegal extraction of major metals and mineral resources. OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Ms. Mary Akrami (executive Director of partner organisation AWN) was selected as member of Peace Consultative Council on 12/07/2020.
(Security and Access to Justice): High Legal Commission consulted CSOs feedback and recommendations for changes in the current laws and policies.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Ms. Mary Akrami (executive Director of partner organisation AWN) was selected as member of Peace Consultative Council on 12/07/2020.
(Security and Access to Justice): High Legal Commission consulted CSOs feedback and recommendations for changes in the current laws and policies.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): The High Peace Council regularly arranges consultation meeting with women and youth to pass their messages to government officials to focus on women & youth meaningful participation in peace talks. During the meetings High Peace Council reaffirmed its commitment soon officially announcement of youth advisory board.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Women advocators (a group of 18 women from 8 provinces) shared their voice and recommendations with State Ministry of Peace. As result, women advocators the jointed the team who are working on women participation mechanism in peace process.

OUTCOME(S): (Inclusive Health): Evidenced based lobby meetings with health and budget committee of parliament on increase of health sector budget in 2020 Afghanistan National Budget conducted with cooperation of Islamic party MPs- Member of Parliament. MPs agreed to organize lobby meetings with health and budget committee of Parliament for health NGOs/CSOs. Both health and budget committee of parliament agreed on importance of health budget increase in 2020 national budget and promised to allocate more budget for health.

title.narrative: H) Government institutions, private sector and civil society develop structural dialogue and engagement

comment.narrative: (Inclusive and engendered peace): (Q4) First Lady continued her support for women rights and peace agenda through funding the peace symposium. First Lady organized a meeting of women & youth with President as well. / (Q2) First Lady is highly committed to women’s right agenda and supporting it. ; MoWA is committed for supporting of women role in peace talk. / (Q1) First Lady is highly committed to women s right agenda and supporting it. In 2017 1st quarter no meeting has been conducted with her. MoWA is committed for supporting of women role in peace talk. / (Security and access to justice): (Q4) Meeting still not started but AWJA,AIBA and APA had agreement to do so. / (Inclusive health services): (Q4) PPP regulation approved my MoJ & MoF and waiting for approval of President. /President Ghani and HPC reaffirm their commitment for involvement of youth in peace talk. Women and Youth advisory board in HPC structure suggested by President. / (Q2) PPP regulation is finalized and passed to MoJ – Ministry of Justice for official approval. ; Community meetings with decision makers for sharing community health issues including insuficient budget started in Nangrahar province and will be extended in other targeted provinces / President Ghani aknowledge role of youth in peace talk and AWN along with CSOs suggested a board for youth in HPC structure in new strategy of peace talk. / (Q1) Government highly committed in involvement of youth in decision making process including peace process and name 1396 as youth year. / (Extractives): (Q4) Targeted local communities participated in provincial development committee meetings and with sectorial local authorities. Complaint hearing mechanism (dialogue & complaint box) between targeted local communities and local authorities developed. Complaint hearing mechanism is method of finding solution for issues related to mining, extractives and production of cement in communities. There are complaint boxes in communities and community members put any issues related to mining and production of cement in the boxes. Each month community members open the boxes and check the issues and select the issue which is common for community. Community share selected issues with relevant government authority and start lobbying for solving the issue. /

Women and Youth advisory board in HPC structure suggested by President. / (Q2) PPP regulation is finalized and passed to MoJ – Ministry of Justice for official approval. ; Community meetings with decision makers for sharing community health issues including insuficient budget started in Nangrahar province and will be extended in other targeted provinces / President Ghani aknowledge role of youth in peace talk and AWN along with CSOs suggested a board for youth in HPC structure in new strategy of peace talk. / (Q1) Government highly committed in involvement of youth in decision making process including peace process and name 1396 as youth year. / (Extractives): (Q4) Targeted local communities participated in provincial development committee meetings and with sectorial local authorities. Complaint hearing mechanism (dialogue & complaint box) between targeted local communities and local authorities developed. Complaint hearing mechanism is method of finding solution for issues related to mining, extractives and production of cement in communities. There are complaint boxes in communities and community members put any issues related to mining and production of cement in the boxes. Each month community members open the boxes and check the issues and select the issue which is common for community. Community share selected issues with relevant government authority and start lobbying for solving the issue. /

(Security and Access to Justice): Judges and prosecutors interacting more with CSOs in targeted provinces particularly on cases of human right violations. Their interactions include attending dialogues, media roundtable discussions and conferences with CSOs. / (Extractives): MoMP and Environmenal Protection agency (NEPA) had diologues at national level with CSOs. A national conference on Mining and Sustainable Development organized by HRRAC which MoMP & NEPA had constructive interaction with CSOs.

Their interactions include attending dialogues, media roundtable discussions and conferences with CSOs. / (Extractives): MoMP and Environmenal Protection agency (NEPA) had diologues at national level with CSOs. A national conference on Mining and Sustainable Development organized by HRRAC which MoMP & NEPA had constructive interaction with CSOs.

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): National justice actors accepted the challenges reported by CSOs and promised for the resolution of them. Following improved coordination at provincial level CSOs are now able to meet national justice actors and raise the issues of justice sector with them for further reforms and improvement.
Attorney General, Deputy Minister of Justice, Dr. Sima Samar (former AIHRC head and Current Satete Minister for Human Rights), Members of Parliament attended Salah’s event titled “National Summit of Peace and Justice”.
(Inclusive Health): Youths CSOs, healthcare NGOs, and MoPH agreed and singed on resolution for the sustainability of the project, and have established a regular exchange through networking. The signed resolution stated support as an active advocator for influencing the members of parliaments for incrementation of national healthcare budget, health insurance law and earmarked taxation.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): The government of Afghanistan conducted a national consultation workshop with women concerning the peace talks. The government of Afghanistan invited a number of women participate in peace negotiations with Taliban and US and international Peace actors in Doha, Islamabad and Moscow, after lobby meetings with partner AWN and intensive campaigning under the name of Women will not Go Back, which included press conferences, press releases and shared press statements to influence the government on meaningful inclusion of women in peace negotiation. (Security and Access to Justice): Main justice stakeholders – Court, Prosecutor’s Office, Department of Justice, CSOs and media in (Balkh, Kunduz, Kandahar, Khost and Nangrahar) - meet once a month during the monthly coordination meetings held by project team and discuss justice issues and challenges. As a result, the level of engagement of Provincial Justice Actors is improving in daily collaboration between actors. Agreements are made and followed-up.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): The government of Afghanistan conducted a national consultation workshop with women concerning the peace talks. The government of Afghanistan invited a number of women participate in peace negotiations with Taliban and US and international Peace actors in Doha, Islamabad and Moscow, after lobby meetings with partner AWN and intensive campaigning under the name of Women will not Go Back, which included press conferences, press releases and shared press statements to influence the government on meaningful inclusion of women in peace negotiation. (Security and Access to Justice): Main justice stakeholders – Court, Prosecutor’s Office, Department of Justice, CSOs and media in (Balkh, Kunduz, Kandahar, Khost and Nangrahar) - meet once a month during the monthly coordination meetings held by project team and discuss justice issues and challenges. As a result, the level of engagement of Provincial Justice Actors is improving in daily collaboration between actors. Agreements are made and followed-up.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Youth in number of coordination meetings developed a joint statement from eight zones (Kabul, Balkh, Herat, Kandahar, Paktia, Nangrahar, Bamyan and Kunduz) to share the women and youth voice to negotiation delegation for the peace talks and the State Ministry of Peace at national level. As result, Youth representative (Khalid Noor) in negotiation team/delegation accepted the youth groups statements from eight zones and promised to include the points in pre negotiation meetings and in negotiation agenda.
(Security and Access to Justice): Police included in online monthly coordination meetings of provincial justice actors- court, prosecutor’s office & department of Justice, CSOs, community representatives – informal justice and media in five targeted provinces (Balkh, Kunduz, Nangarhar, Kandahar & Khost). As a result, formal and informal justice providers are discussing and coordinating case referrals in monthly meetings. Based on criteria, cases are referring from formal to informal and vice versa.
(Extractives): Coordination group among local government, CSOs, and communities, developed in Badakhshan and Panjshir provinces of Afghanistan, discussing the mining issues locally. in result of improved coordiantion ,actors like provincial government, CSOs, and communities having access to mining information.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): three youth participated in roundtable discussion and reflected the role of youth in peace process on national TVs (Shamshad TV, Aryana and National TV), following advocacy towards Ministry of Peace and Ministry of Information and Culture and sharing a list of youth to have their participation in event regarding youth participation in peace process.
/ (Extractives): The Ministry of Mining and Petroleum (MoMP) signed various key MoUs with private sector, environment agencies, and CSOs for sharing information, accountability and following up on the responsibilities contained in the MoUs.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): three youth participated in roundtable discussion and reflected the role of youth in peace process on national TVs (Shamshad TV, Aryana and National TV), following advocacy towards Ministry of Peace and Ministry of Information and Culture and sharing a list of youth to have their participation in event regarding youth participation in peace process.
/ (Extractives): The Ministry of Mining and Petroleum (MoMP) signed various key MoUs with private sector, environment agencies, and CSOs for sharing information, accountability and following up on the responsibilities contained in the MoUs.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Ministry of Information and Culture promised to include youth and women representatives from SP youth and women groups in the media roundtables about peace and peace talks. (Security and Access to Justice): CSOs and media monitor court cases regularly for record of human rights violations. Provincial justice actors- court, prosecutor’s office & department of justice welcomed the complaint boxes installed by SP partner – Salah, in five targeted provinces of Afghanistan (Balkh, Kunduz, Nangrahar, Kandahar & Khost). Communities are using the complaints boxes and Salah lead local CSOs jointly with provincial justice actors open the boxes in monthly basis and discuss the issues. As result of court cases monitoring, implementation of court procedures and fair trail improved in five targeted provinces (Balkh, Kunduz, Nangrahar, Kandahar & Khost) (Inclusive Health): One pager for Revenue Generation Strategic Framework and one pager for Health Insurance Law approved by Ministry of Public Health – MoPH. Both one pager will be used as fact sheet and evidence for lobby and advocacy on approval of Health Insurance Law. (Extractives): Local government authorities in targeted provinces (Panjshir & Badakhshan) are participating in the community & CSOs meetings and dialogues about mining to address local communities' concerns about mining. As a result, coordination group among local government, CSOs and communities developed in Panjshir and Badakhshan province, and they meet monthly and discuss local communities’ mining issue. Mining stakeholders including government and CSOs are more cooperative, agreed on extractives trajectory goal and objectives and share their recommendation and suggestions for better implementation of ToC in national and provincial level.

Youth associations participated in the conference. Deputy Minister again confirmed the role youth in peace talk and asked from youth from their strong involvement in peace process / (Q1) Deputy Minister actively support role of youth in peace talk through media and public events. Youth mandated CSOs sensitize HPC and President though 08 March and coordination meetings. / (Extractives): (Q4) Partner HRRAC recently got the membership of Afghanistan Mining Watch, ENRMN and MSG group.They are actively participating in discussion around mining. / (Q2) Coradid and SP partner HRRAC have been participated in AITTI meetings.

(Security and Access to Justice): Supreme Court engaged with CSOs and had discussion with CSOs on justice issues in national level press conference and celebration of international Human Rights Day

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Deputy Minister of Youth brought youths participation in peace talks into cabinet meeting agenda. President promised to include women and youth representatives in Doha peace talks conference. As result, women and youth representatives participated in Doha peace conference. / Minister of Peace promised and committed to include women and youth representatives in negotiation delegation of government in next round of peace talks with Taliban. The delegation list will be announced soon by government. (Security and Access to Justice): Provincial justice actors- court, prosecutor’s office & department of justice in five targeted provinces accepted the gaps and challenges in justice sector, discussed in the coordination meetings. For addressing the gaps, they agreed to have CSOs cooperation and asked SP partner – Salah, for organizing trainings on newly enacted legislations to capacitate their staff. (Inclusive Health): National health insurance advocacy forum conducted with about 50 participants of MoPH, Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (MoLSA), parliament, senate, ministries, health NGOs, international NGOs, UN agencies and media. All participants of the forum agreed and signed a petition (declaration of commitment) as an active supporter/advocator for approval of Health Insurance Law and petition shared with MoPH, MoJ, MoF and Parliament. (Extractives): Through dialogues and lobby meetings of CSOs, communities and media with the government at national and local level, government institutions are more proactive in exchange of information with CSOs, communities and media. Ministry of Mine and Petroleum - MoMP, is consulting with CSOs in developing/revising mining policies and procedures. Government agreed to increase of collaboration with CSOs in the mining sector, including signing MoUs , information sharing and agreement to work with local communities around mining in Panjshir and Badikhshan province of Afghanistan.

title.narrative: E) Communities organize inclusive dialogue in which women, youth and minority groups can voice their needs and concerns

comment.narrative: (Inclusive and engendered peace): (Q4) PPCs have regular meetings after a period of being unfunctional and process of more involvement women in PPCs are ongoing. / ) Women concerns collected from women mandated CSOs and shared with PPCs in targeted in provinces. / (Q2) Women mandated CSOs and women activists collected women's recommendations through consultation workshops in targeted provinces and shared with PPCs. /(Q2) Women & youth issues in involvement in peace talk collected through consultation workshops and shared with PPCs for their consideration. / (Q1) Recommendations of women advocator (including PPCs female member) shared with HPC and President. / Women mandated CSOs and women activists collected women s recommendations through consultation workshops in targeted provinces and shared with PPCs. / (Extractives): (Q4) Youth committees actively participating in discussions, awareness raising sessions and dialogues between community and government. / (Q2) Two youth committees were selected and started regular meetings. / (Q1) Partner organization preparing activities with local communities. /

(Inclusive and engendered peace): (Q4) PPCs have regular meetings after a period of being unfunctional and process of more involvement women in PPCs are ongoing. / ) Women concerns collected from women mandated CSOs and shared with PPCs in targeted in provinces. / (Q2) Women mandated CSOs and women activists collected women's recommendations through consultation workshops in targeted provinces and shared with PPCs. /(Q2) Women & youth issues in involvement in peace talk collected through consultation workshops and shared with PPCs for their consideration. / (Q1) Recommendations of women advocator (including PPCs female member) shared with HPC and President. / Women mandated CSOs and women activists collected women s recommendations through consultation workshops in targeted provinces and shared with PPCs. / (Extractives): (Q4) Youth committees actively participating in discussions, awareness raising sessions and dialogues between community and government. / (Q2) Two youth committees were selected and started regular meetings. / (Q1) Partner organization preparing activities with local communities. /

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): Local communities’ in targeted provinces are now well informed on the justice system, and there is high interest from local people to solve their cases through the formal justice system.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Community women shared their voice through social media and brought more discussion to women involvement in peace process. Community meetings with local women in eight targeted provinces (Kabul, Herat, Kandahar, Paktia, Bamyan, Nangrahar, Balkh & Kunduz) created a unity amongst local women to conduct advocacy for involvement of women in peace process.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): In Peace Campaigns and community gatherings women and youth affected from war tell stories about how the war impediments their life, families, and community, and the communities discuss the significance of peace and valuable role of women and youth in the peace process. 800 community members participated the peace campaign held by partner organisation AWN in Kabul, Herat, Balkh, Kandahar, Bamyan, Nangrahar, Paktia and Kunduz.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Urban area youth in targeted provinces conducted awareness raising session for rural community members by having street campaign on peace and importance of peace in community development. As result, connection between rural and urban youth developed for further local outreach on peace process, and rural area youth are now also conducting awareness raising for their communities.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Media – TVs, broadcasted more about role of youths and women in peace talks at national and local level in eight targeted provinces(Kabul, Herat, Kandahar, Paktia, Bamyan, Nangrahar, Balkh & Kunduz). They conducted several roundtable discussions about youth participation in peace talks.

title.narrative: D) CSOs organize in networks to build collaborate capacity for lobby and advocacy

comment.narrative: (Security and Access to Justice): A network of CSOs in five targeted provinces is developed and have regular monthly meetings. Justice sector represetatives and media are also inviting in monthly meetings. / (Extractives): Local network of CSOs developed in Parwan province of Afghanistan and capacitateded in lobby and advocacy.

(Security and Access to Justice): A network of CSOs in five targeted provinces is developed and have regular monthly meetings. Justice sector represetatives and media are also inviting in monthly meetings. / (Extractives): Local network of CSOs developed in Parwan province of Afghanistan and capacitateded in lobby and advocacy.

OUTCOME(S): (Inclusive Health): NGOs and CSOs whom they are working on health sector of Afghanistan agreed with lobby point to increase health sector budget and they agreed to have joint lobby as a CSO coalition with Afghanistan President, MoF, parliament and donors. Afghanistan health NGOs coordination meetings (Afghan Midwife Association, AHO and private hospital association) will be used as a coordination platform.

OUTCOME(S): (Inclusive Health): The National Advocacy Committee- for Public Policy on Health (NAC-PP), a platform with 83 CSOs members with 6 subcommittees, established a regular exchange mechanism with SP partner AHDS for joint lobby and advocacy meetings, workshops and events. OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): Provincial justice actors (court, prosecutor’s office & department of justice) welcomed the complaint boxes installed by SP partner – Salah, in five targeted provinces (Balkh, Kunduz, Nangrahar, Kandahar & Khost). As result, communities are using the complaints boxes. Salah, local CSOs and provincial justice actors jointly open the complaint boxes in monthly basis and discuss the issues. Local CSOs follow up the issue addressed in complaint box with provincial justice actors.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): TVs and Radios stations in targeted provinces (Kabul, Herat, Nangrahar, Kandahar, Paktia, Bamyan, Balkh and Kunduz) invited youth and women for peace dialogue in roundtable discussions.

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): CSOs and media monitor court cases regularly for record of human rights violations. As result of court cases monitoring, implementation of court procedures and fair trail improved in five targeted provinces (Balkh, Kunduz, Nangrahar, Kandahar & Khost)

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): Formal justice actors – Courts, Department of Justice and Prosecutors and informal justice in 5 targeted provinces (Balkh, Kunduz, Kandahar, Khost and Nangrahar) accept the gaps and challenges in justice sector as presented in the study by (Salah?) and agreed to address the weak points.

title.narrative: L) International development actors support inclusive development and peace and state-building processes in fragile contexts

comment.narrative: OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Afghan women activists developed a position paper by lead of AWN and AWN shared it with France Parliament and US Congress for role and participation of women representatives in peace talks. MPs in France and US Parliament welcomed the paper and promised to emphasize on role of Afghan women on peace talks.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Women Afghan activist from different parts of the country including members of AWN established an advocacy group to strongly voice women concern at national and international platform and they shared their recommendations to USA delegations and congress, in which Ms. Hillary Clinton and members of the USA congress strongly called on Afghan government to strongly consider the participation of women in peace negotiation and intra Afghan peace talks.

title.narrative: Safe Jaded | NAP III Afghanistan

description.narrative: Departmental Offices of Defense, Interior, Justice and Women Affairs, Gender Mainstreaming Units at District and Provincial Level, Provincial Councils, Provincial Women’s Networks/ Advocacy Groups/Advocacy Committees/Women mandated CSOs, Magistrates, Religious and tribal leaders, Youth Groups, Shuras and jirgas, and Local media

The Safe Jaded project, which is funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) of the Netherlands, is a three year project (started in January 2017, ending in December 2019), which is implemented by three national (Woman and Peace Study Organization, Hamida Barmaki Rule of Law Organization, Afghan Women Education Center) and two international consortium partners (Cordaid and Oxfam) with Oxfam as the leading partner. This project is a follow up of the Bayan II project (Bayan II – Inclusive Governance and Improved Security through Influencing) and covers six provinces (Herat, Balkh, Parwan, Nangarhar, Daikundi, and Paktia) and aims to contribute to the creation of enabling environment for participation and increased protection of women and girls in Afghanistan, and the implementation and monitoring of Afghanistan’s National Action Plan 1325 on Women, Peace and Security.

description.narrative: In DRCongo: for the Global Fund programme on HIV/AIDS 3 contracts were signed during the period 2010-2017.As of 2018 Cordaid is primary recipient for both HIV and TB in 24 provinces in DRC, the total budget is almost 150 M USD. This current programme will run until end 2020. First step was that the CCM - Country Coordination Mechanism in DRC submits a Concept note to the GF. Cordaid, as one of the primary recipients, has been involved in the development of the CN.

Total population of DRC.  General population;  HIV-positive mothers and their newborns;  PLWHA and people affected by HIV/AIDS;  TB patients;  Coinfected people;  Key populations: Sex workers; Men who have sex with men and transgenders; UDIs;prisoners;  Adolescent girls and young women

 Contribute to the reduction of HIV/AIDS in DRC and their consequences in the population  Ensure global care and treatment of all TB/HIV co-infected patients in DRC  Contribute to the reduction of 20% of TB related mortality by 2020.

Appui au Renforcement du Système de Santé en RCA (Fonds Bêkou III)

description.narrative: The final beneficiaries is the population (estimated at 469,941 inhabitants in 2018) covered by the 56 health facilities (3 hospitals, 38 Health Centers and 15 health posts), of the 38 health catchment areas of the 3 targeted Health Districts (Bangassou:4 communes and total population 137,345, Ouango-Gambo: 5 communes and total population 88,718 Bossangoa; 6 communes and total population 243 878.

The main aim of this third phase is to continue to strengthen the health system with an integrated approach at the Health District level providing decentralized services offering within the a universal health coverage using a RBF approach. There are 4 specific objectives: - to improve all aspects of health care quality; - to strengthen community participation - to strengthen the technical and financial management capacity of the COGES. In the project, Cordaid will also train and coach the Bêkou Fund health partner organizations (ALIMA, CRF, PUI and IMC) in the process of introducing the PBF approach into their project.

Urban resilience in one ward of Hlaing Tar Yar township in Yangon

description.narrative:
Direct beneficiaries: 10.800 people (Inner Padan: 10.000; 2 new wards: 800 (400 per ward).
Indirect beneficiaries: 110.100 people * Inner Padan: 8.000 (Total population Inner Padan 18.000; 8.000 expected to be benefitting indirectly). * Ward 10: 16.100 people (7.600 males; 8.500 females) (As research ward) * Yay Oakkan village: 42.200 people (19.100 males, 23.100 females) * Nyaung village: 43.800 people (21.600 male; 22.200)
The direct target group consists of the selected people of the population of the three wards targeted by the project. Inner Padan, the ward already selected in 2018, has a group of direct beneficiaries of 10.000 people who will use the clean water. Nyaung village and Yay Oakkan will involve 400 people for the PDRA.
The indirect target group of the project consists of all inhabitants of the wards/villages selected, because they will benefit of the DRR measures which will be implemented. With the increased attention for resilience in the ward/village, their resiliency will also increase.

The envisioned project results are:
· Resilient community action plan (development plans and contingency plans) have been developed and are owned by the stakeholders based on the participatory risk assessments and multi-stakeholder analysis
· There is increased collaboration between the stakeholders, the platform is operational and well-functioning, and the community and local authorities are a driving force behind the platform
· DRR measures have been collaboratively developed, implemented and a plan for operation and maintenance / monitoring is in place

Yangon has high precipitation of about 2,750 mm of rain annually. When flooding occurs in the area of Hlaing Tar Yar Township, thousands of people are directly affected of which the most vulnerable households, the squatters, are even more affected as they inhabit the least developed areas. There are no emergency plans put in place and when hazards occur decisions have to be taken on the spot. Households surveyed in Hlaing Tar Yar have very low resilience against shocks of any kind. Average income per capita is below 2 $ per day. Household debts are high and there are no other coping mechanisms than borrowing additional money from money lenders, which in the long run will decrease the resilience of individuals and households even more. Among these households the incidence of severely malnourished children under 5 is high.

title.narrative: SRHR Yemen

description.narrative:
Context Analysis Yemen Sept 2020
The war that started at the beginning of 2015 has escalated over time. It is impossible to give a brief and complete overview that includes all the nuances and complexities. The war between the Houthi movement and the internationally recognized government of President Hadi is the result of a failed political transition after the Arab Spring in 2011. In the meantime the Houthi movement has taken the capital of Sanaa and is still expanding its zone of control. The international recognized government - that is in exile in Saudi Arabia – is losing territory over time. Saudi Arabia is supporting the Hadi government. Iran is supporting the Houthi movement. The war is now fragmenting. The main warring parties are fragmenting regionally and locally in different groups. There are now more warring factions and frontlines than ever. Also aerial bombardments still occur. The escalation of the war has devastating humanitarian consequences for the population.
The crisis in Yemen is the worst in the world, and all indicators point towards a massive deterioration. There is no other country in the world with a higher percentage of people in need of some sort of humanitarian assistance or protection in order to survive. 80% of Yemen’s population need our help – there is no other country with comparable statistics. Half of all of the people in Yemen are what we call acutely vulnerable, meaning that they will not make it without the assistance we provide them. There is no other country on earth where half the population is acutely vulnerable. • 2/3 of the entire population wakes up hungry everyday • 1/4 of the population is malnourished
The UN-run humanitarian operation in Yemen is the largest UN humanitarian operation in the world – 11 UN agencies and 215 frontline partners are providing all kinds of aid and assistance throughout the country. One of the largest food programs in UN history is being run in Yemen, with the World Food Programme delivering food to 14 million people – half of the Yemeni population. We reached close to 11 million people with healthcare before the pandemic, and we were reaching 9 million people with water and sanitation before the funding crisis. The crisis has gotten significantly worse throughout the war. While Yemen was always poor, but with every year of war the number of people humanitarian assistance has increased. From 15 million people in need of help when the war started, next year 16 million, after that 20 million and now 25 million. The crisis has multiple waves: - Yemen has experienced the worst cholera outbreak in modern history - Famine - Once-in-a-generation flooding - Unchecked, unmitigated spread of COVID-19, with probably the highest case mortality rate in the world - Once again a famine is appearing.
The situation is going to get worse until the warring parties put down arms.
Funding and operational crisis The International Community (IC) has a funding crisis and an operational crisis too. While commending the generosity of donors throughout the war, this year the I.C only received USD $1 billion of the $3.2 billion needed. The UN has 41 major programmes, and the past 4 months we have been forced to shut down or reduce 15 of the programmes. Without additional funding the next few weeks, another 26 programmes face the same risk. The consequences will of course be death and suffering. The operational crisis referred to has to do with our abilities as humanitarians to deliver assistance in accordance with the four core humanitarian principles. These are the principles of humanity, independence, impartiality and neutrality. Most of the problems we face are in northern Yemen. When faced with cases where the IC simply cannot deliver in accordance with those principles, it is forced to roll back the assistance it is providing until it is able to manage the level of risk we are facing. There is no more restrictive, non-permissive operating environment in the world than the one in Yemen.
For the voucher program we will to work in one health district which is Utmah in the governate of Dhamar,26 with a population of 235,000 people.

title.narrative: Humanitarian Assistance for IDPs, returnees, and host communities in Herat, Afghanistan

description.narrative: For decades Herat has been harbouring conflict and natural disaster affected IDPs and returnees. With the conflict intensifying, lack of rain and changing political situation, their numbers are rapidly increasing surpassing the absorption capacity of the communities. People are food insecure, need access to land, shelter, and basic services.
Target group: Conflict and drought affected IDPs, returnees, and host communities. In total 27,300 individuals are expected to be reached.
To ensure that the life-saving protection and assistance needs of conflict, natural disaster affected and internally displaced persons, returning Afghans and their host community are met.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Saving Lives Corporate Indicators
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: CSH-I2: Number of people benefitting from conditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: A conditional transfer requires beneficiaries to undertake a specific action/activity (e.g. attending school, building a shelter, attending nutrition screenings, undertaking work, trainings, etc.) in order to receive assistance; i.e. a condition must be fulfilled before the transfer is received. Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). Conditional cash transfers can include cash for work, cash for assets and cash for training.

title.narrative: CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

Flood Resilience in Myanmar Dry Zone.

description.narrative: Pakokku Township is located in Magway region, in the centre of Myanmar. The economy of the Township is defined by agriculture, especially in the rural areas. Pakokku has five different zones, reflecting on their environmental profile: 1) Pakokku town; 2) riverbank areas; 3) seasonal flash flood (wet-dry) areas; 4) inland dry areas; and 5) mountain dry areas. These zones are differently influenced by natural hazards. The main challenge in the township is the vulnerability related to water. The dry zone receives little rain (average of 650mm) on an annual basis. However, during July-October storms, it floods quickly in the area, partly because of decreasing forest cover and soil erosion. This places communities at higher risk of localised flash floods during times of heavy rain. The targeted community is located along the Ayeyarwaddy river bank. As a result of climate change and the uncertainty of climatic conditions, plus deforestation and changed land-use, hydrological risks are increasing, especially in flood prone areas. Additionally, the area has a very unbalanced sex ratio, because of the out-migration of men. Also the infant mortality is considerably higher than the national average.

The aim of the project is to build the resilience of (13) communities in Pakokku Township and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social, and environmental shocks and disasters.

The project targets 13 villages in Pakokku Township, with a total number of 1511 households, consisting of 7395 individuals (3,473 male and 3,922 female). The direct benefit of improved resilience will improve the resilience of the whole township, through increased attention on this topic and disaster risk reduction measures which are carried out. The indirect target group has 29 villages and a population of approximately 10,150.

participating-org.narrative: KMSS - Karuna Mission Social Solidarity (Caritas Myanmar)

Strengthening The Health System In Jimma Zone

description.narrative:
General Objective: “Improved availability and accessibility of good quality healthcare at primary and secondary level in the Jimma Zone (Oromia Region, Ethiopia), and a stronger health system at large, which supports the progressive realization of Universal Health Coverage (SDG 3.8) in this geographical area.”
The three (inter-related) targeted Outcomes are:
1. Improved Health Service Delivery in 13 woredas of the Jimma Zone, reflected in: A. Increased utilization of good quality services B. Increased equity in access
2. Improved governance of health service delivery through: A. Increased capacity of 13 Woreda Health Offices and 1 Zonal Health Department B. Institutionalisation of PBF in the Ethiopian health system
3. An enhanced health information system that supports: A. Data based decision making at Woreda, Zonal and Regional level B. Additional financing potential for health system through enhanced transparency

In Ethiopia, Cordaid started to showcase Performance Based Financing in the arid and pastoralist Borana zone of the Oromia region since May 1st, 2015. At first in 4 Borana districts and with 9 Health facilities but as of July 2018 scaling it up to 8 Borana districts with in total 25 Health facilities with a catchment population of 488,556. Both PBF Borana phases are supported by Cordaid funds.
Halfway 2018 Cordaid was invited by the Netherlands Embassy to formulate a four year proposal and budget for scaling up PBF in the rural coffee growing zone of Jimma. Early April 2019 the Embassy approved the four year project proposal using as starting date the 1st of April 2019. During the first six months the project will be set up and staff recruited and trained. The first quarter for which the health facilities will be contracted under PBF will be October to December 2019.

The project will focus on 13 Jimma zone districts (of the in total 21 Jimma districts). It will work mostly via health facilities. In total 65 Health Centers and 5 Hospitals will be contracted under the PBF project. In total these facilities have a catchment population of 1.828.148 people living in the 13 targeted districts of the Jimma zone.

title.narrative: Emergency Response Earthquake Sulawesi

description.narrative:
Humanitarian emergency life saving response after the earthquake/ tsunami in Sulawesi, Indonesia. Giro555 started a National Appeal on October 2nd to raise funds for the victims of the disaster and Cordaid is a member agency that is supporting a local partner network on humanitarian response.
To ensure early recovery (3-8 months after disaster) and resilient recovery (8-24 months after disaster) to prevent the disaster to recur

Indonesia was struck by a 7.5 magnitude followed by a tsunami on 29 September 2018, killing so far more than 800 people and affecting directly and indirectly more than 2 million people. Local infrastructure was heavily destroyed and the population now struggle to survive. There are high needs in shelter, WASH, food and non-food items, but access is a challenge due to destruction. The government has officially requested for international assistance.
People affected by the earthquake. Target: 2000 HH or 8000 people

participating-org.narrative: LPTP - Lembanga Pengembangan Teknologi Predesaan Indonesia

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Solid waste management
WSH-I5: Number of people living in settlements with a functional solid waste management system

description.narrative: Solid waste of all households of the settlements as well as commercial waste is removed stored safely and removed regularly with equipment and frequency according to standards (Sphere). Risk of solid waste pollution of environment is kept to a minimum. Medical waste is managed separately according to standards to minimize risk. System implies: planning and implementation in consultation with affected populations and relevant authorities, taking into account refuse type and quantity, incl. medical, burial, market etc; adequate disposal with minimum risk; attention to staff welfare.

title.narrative: Excreta disposal
WSH-I2: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Access: ratio (user/facility) of 1 toilet for a max. 20 people, distance < 50 metres from dwellings, or as locally agreed. Clean: regular cleaning and maintenance for public facilities. Dignified: Use of toilets respect cultural preference and is arranged by household(s) and/or segregated by sex. Unsafe facilities: unstable (unlined) pits with risk of collapse, pits accessible to vectors, pits contaminating water tables and poorly sited facilities which expose women and girls to attacks, especially at night. Functional facility: fully constructed, in working order and properly maintained, of a type and in a location acceptable to intended users, with hand washing facilities and anal cleansing material.

title.narrative: Non-food items

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

Burundi KfW Improvement access to SRH through RBF Phase II

description.narrative: Le groupe cible du programme est la population des provinces de Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro regroupant environ 1,7 millions d’habitants et particulièrement les femmes en âge de procréation et les enfants de moins de 5 ans ainsi que les jeunes. Le premier niveau d’intervention du programme est le niveau décentralisé le plus bas des services de santé, à savoir les ASC qui sont regroupés en GASC et les FOSA au nombre de 75 dans la province de GITEGA dont 65 CDS (60 avec contrat principal et 5 contrats secondaires) et 10 hôpitaux (7 avec contrat principal et 3 contrats secondaires), 29 dans la province de MURAMVYA dont 27 CDS (24 avec contrat principal et 3 contrat secondaire) et 2 hôpitaux (avec contrat principal) et 28 dans la province de MWARO dont 26 CDS et 2 hôpitaux.

Les évènements de l’année 2015, ont fragilisé le Burundi dans plusieurs domaines de la vie du pays sur le plan interne et externe notamment dans ses relations de coopération internationale avec d’autres pays et la communauté internationale . Ainsi, plusieurs pays ont suspendu les appuis directs au gouvernement du Burundi. Dans le même cadre , le gouvernement allemand a suspendu en parti ses activités dans le pays jusqu'à nouvel ordre. Cependant, dans le souci de sauvegarder les acquis dans le système de santé burundais, le gouvernement allemand a décidé d’appuyer ce système par l’intermédiaire de l’Organisation non-gouvernementale (ONG) Cordaid (Bénéficiaire), pour améliorer la situation de la population la plus démunie, à travers un projet intitulé « Renforcement de la santé sexuelle et reproductive à travers le Financement basé sur la performance. La promière phase de ce projet d'un budget de 5 millions d'euros, a durée 2 ans, et a commencé le 31 décembre 2017 pour prendre fin le 28 Février 2020. La deuxième phase va durer 3 ans allant du 9 Avril 2020 au 31 mars 2023 et couvre trois provinces sanitaires ( Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro).

L’objectif général du projet est de contribuer à l’amélioration de la santé de la population burundaise, notamment des femmes, des nouveau-nés, des enfants et des jeunes dans les provinces de Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro. L’objectif spécifique du programme est de contribuer à l’augmentation des services de santé de base de bonne qualité notamment en matière de santé reproductive (SR) à travers l’approche de Financement Basé sur la Performance (FBP) dans les provinces de Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro.

title.narrative: Creating Access for Inclusive Peace Processes in Afghanistan

description.narrative: Afghanistan has suffered from over four decades of war. While there was a measure of progress during the last 18 years, there are widespread concerns that that women’s rights and other social gains could be reversed with the potential return of the Taliban to the political order. The absence of women in formal peace negotiations has heightened these concerns. To protect women and girls’ rights and the gains achieved, women and civil society have to be capacitated to strategically and meaningfully contribute to the peace processes and to demonstrate that women and girls’ rights and a rights-based agenda has a broad based support in Afghan society. Likewise, more diversified perspectives on all matters concerning the peace talks will lead to stronger peace outcomes. They will, in particular, have to be prepared to make a case within an Islamic framework to counter traditional and religious groups supporting regressive gender norms.
Improved institutional rights and inclusive participation of women and girls in the Afghan peace processes.

The program will be implemented in Afghanistan, in close collaboration with the Afghan Women’s Network. Women, men and civil society actors from throughout the country, particularly conflict affected areas, will be engaged through the selection of the Advisory Committee, the Core Group, the Circle of Allies, consultations and other activities devised by the Advisory Committee. It will also support the capacity of this group to engage in peacemaking opportunities inside and outside Afghanistan, including Qatar, Norway and other locations where Afghan peace related initiatives are convened.

description.narrative: 31620 primary beneficiaries, mainly women; 19190 other direct beneficiaries

Impact: Women’s mobilization and advocacy at local, district, provincial and national levels contributes to creating a safer, more just and more peaceful Afghanistan for all
Objective 1: Enhance existing and new PWNs' capacity to collect and use evidence for advocacy purposes, establishing new PWNs in 19 provinces and supporting all 34 PWNs to conduct research and participatory analysis on relevant policy issues.
Objective 2: Stimulate systematic responsiveness and accountability from security, justice and governance duty-bearers and power-holders on the basis of effective mobilization and advocacy by women.
Objective 3: Promote inclusion of women’s voices in Afghan peace processes at all levels.

Since the removal of the Taliban in 2001 and the establishment of the current republic, Afghan women have mobilized to successfully demand widespread changes intended to improve gender equality and women’s empowerment. Gains achieved by women under the Government of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan (GoIRA) are not insubstantial, yet women continue to face discrimination and human rights abuses. Patriarchal social norms and institutionalized exclusion combine to prevent women and girls from accessing the services they are entitled to as citizens; this is especially true of the security and justice services they need to access protection from pervasive (sexual- and) gender-based violence, or (S)GBV, or for justice when such violence occurs. Likewise, women are generally excluded from public decision-making, including meaningful contribution to Afghanistan’s peace processes, from the local to the highest policy levels, and thereby prevented from helping to shape the country’s future.

title.narrative: Creating Opportunities to Earn and Improve Employability among Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees in Kandahar and Herat

description.narrative:
(M)SMEs below the age of 40 with growth potential;
Young IDPs and Returnees;

The proposed action – implemented through a consortium constituting the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Cordaid – seeks to create jobs and income earning opportunities for displaced people and vulnerable host communities in Afghanistan, through private sector growth. It aims to build on and complement the Government of Afghanistan’s flagship EZ-Kar programme, a five-year project funded by the World Bank, the European Union, and other donors which aims to “strengthen the enabling environment for economic opportunities in cities where there is a high influx of displaced people”.
More specifically, the proposed action is designed to complement EZ-Kar’s Component 2.2, which seeks to improve the market-enabling infrastructure in urban centres. This action will capitalise on the enhanced business environment created by EZ-Kar to increase the number of jobs created by local businesses, and, crucially, ensure that displaced populations benefit from these new job opportunities. This action therefore includes two main pillars: on the one hand, supporting micro, small and medium enterprise (MSMEs) who benefit from EZ-Kar’s enhanced business environment to further grow their business and create jobs; on the other hand, supporting youth from displaced and vulnerable host community families living in those areas to secure and retain decent jobs in these MSMEs.

Performance Based Financing in Borana zone 2020-2022

description.narrative: A total of 488.556 people living in the catchment area of (maximum) 25 targeted Health Facilities (or a total of 793,365 people, if we take the total catchment population of the two hospitals included in Phase II) in the 8 project Woredas will benefit from the project implementation.

Ethiopia has made steady improvements towards achieving its main health goals. There is good progress in reducing mortality and morbidity among children and women. Over the last two decades, the under-five mortality rate declined from 166 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2000 to 67 in 2016 and infant mortality rate (IMR) declined from 97 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2000 to 48 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2016. Between 2000 and 2016, Contraceptive Prevalence Rate increased from 8 percent to 36 percent; births attended by skilled attendants increased from 6 percent to 28 percent and maternal mortality (although still high) declined from 871 maternal deaths per 100 000 live births in 2000 to 412 in 2016. However, Ethiopia remains one of the poorest countries in the world with lagging indicators in maternal and child health, especially neonatal mortality. Equitable access to basic services is a concern, while quality of services and readiness of facilities to provide quality services is a major hindrance to Universal Health Coverage (UHC). Financial protection from serious illness remains inadequate and is one of the most challenging agendas for the next decades.
In Ethiopia, Cordaid started to showcase PBF in the arid and pastoralist Borana zone. After a participatory design process of six months, the project officially started on May 1st, 2015. Stakeholders involved in the design of the PBF project in Borana were among others the Oromia Regional Health Bureau (ORHB), the Borana Zonal Health Department (ZHD) and 4 Woreda (district) Health Offices. Phase I of the PBF project ended on the 30th of June 2018. Since the results were positive, and contributed to an increase in both the utilisation and the quality of health care services, the Borana ZHD and Cordaid jointly designed Phase II: scaling up from 4 to 8 woredas, from 9 to 25 health facilities and from a catchment population of 125,918 to a population of 488,556. Phase II started in July 2018 and will end by December 2019. Both phases are supported by Cordaid own funding.

Improved availability and accessibility of good quality healthcare at primary and secondary level in the Borana Zone (Oromia Region, Ethiopia), and a stronger health system at large, which supports the progressive realization of Universal Health Coverage (SDG 3.8) in this geographical area.” transparency

title.narrative: Individual household shelter
SHL-I1: Number of people having access to basic, safe and dignified shelters solutions

description.narrative: Basic, safe and dignified: - affected individuals have an minimum covered floor area of 3.5m2 per person. - all shelter solutions and materials meet locally agreed technical and performance standards and are culturally acceptable. - all household (re-)construction is in accordance with safe building practices and standards. - all household (re-)construction demonstrate involvement of the affected population and/or are culturally acceptable by the affected population.

title.narrative: Saving Lives Corporate Indicators
CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (SL)
